@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Edit:

I’ve now added a playerlist feature. It uses a unique ID to get the new links, unlike before where it used player names.

item.title: PDO returning duplicates?
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

@The Web Guy: Seems overly complicated…

[code=java]
Connection connection = …
PreparedStatement statement = connection.prepareStatement(“INSERT INTO bank (player_id, slot, id, amount) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?);”);

statement.setInt(1, player.getDatabaseId());

Item[] items = player.getBankItems();
for (int slot = 0; slot < items.length; slot++) {
statement.setInt(2, slot);

Item item = items[slot];

if (item == null) {
    statement.setNull(3, Types.INTEGER);
    statement.setNull(4, Types.INTEGER);
} else {
    statement.setInt(3, item.getId());
    statement.setInt(4, item.getAmount());
}

statement.addBatch();

}

statement.executeBatch();[/code]

Something like this would be the best approach.

Schema of:
smallint -> player_id
smallint -> slot
smallint -> id
int -> amount

Read full topic

item.title: PDO returning duplicates?
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

There are three options to saving the bank.

  1. Insert each slot into a database with the following columns: UID, Slot, ItemID, ItemAmt …
  2. Build an array server-sided of all the slots, all the item ids, all the item amounts. So the columns in SQL would be like this: UID, slots, ids, amounts… Then just break down the data website sided.
  3. If you wanted to try it a different way… Have two SQL columns: UID, bank
    Bank would contain something like this:
    slot1, item1id, item1amt; slot2, item2id, item2amt

Then just do a few lines of code to determine that ; is the delimiter that breaks the string into multiple slots. However, this would include having to build a very long string/array server-sided.

Which one do you guys think is fastest?

Read full topic

item.title: PDO returning duplicates?
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

Yes. It doesn’t hurt to have 600+ rows per player. Make sure the player name is an index to help speed things up a bit. Although I still think string searches would be slow, so if you can assign a uniquely generated id to each character when they’re created you can use that for your look up.

Read full topic

item.title: PDO returning duplicates?
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:14, topic:544018”][quote author=AtomicInt_ link=topic=662899.msg4430349#msg4430349 date=1402976362]

The table it’s loading from contains like 702 columns.

Please tell me you’re joking…

I’m not. The database has 702 columns in it. It sounds ridiculous, but there’s 1 for each item slot and the item amount.
The loop stops when it hits the first item with an ID of lower than one.

You mean rows… I hope
[/quote]
No… It’s one table for all users.
350 bank slots + 350 bank slot item amounts + playername + id = 702.[/quote]
Microsoft have great tutorials and docs on how you can properly do your shittt

Read full topic
